title: The Bot Delusion. Large language models and anticipated consequences for academics’ publication and citation behavior
abstract: The reproduction of social inequalities through artificial intelligence and large language models (LLMs) has been demonstrated empirically in various areas of society, for example in policing and personnel hiring decisions. Yet, a broader discussion is missing to what extent LLMs may affect the scientific enterprise, reinforce or mitigate existing structural inequalities, and introduce a “bot delusion” in academia. Focusing on publications and citations behavior, we devise a thought experiment regarding the impact of LLMs. These differentiate between the reproduction of preexisting structurally conditioned inequalities in science (socio-cognitive stasis), or to a catharsis, that may counteract structural inequalities and Matthew Effects. We develop three scenarios of the consequences of using LLMs for citations: The LLM anticipated consequences are reproducing content and status quo (scenario 1), enabling content coherence evaluation (scenario 2) and content evaluation (scenario 3). In face of the fast-paced evolution of LLMs, to attribute meaning to anticipated consequences on citations from a sociological perspective, we discuss the normative significance of LLM-use for selecting citations. Considered as ideal types, Merton’s CUDOS norms of communalism, universalism, disinterestedness, and organized skepticism capture the catharsis opportunity offered by LLM, and stasis is reflected in the Mitroff’s SPIOD counter-norms of secrecy, particularism, self-interestedness and organized dogmatism. As SPIOD only captures individual counter-norms, we introduce communal counter-norms to capture academics’ loyal citation behavior. The latter insinuates a status quo future of science (scenario 1), while the mixed-access (scenario 2) and open science (scenario 3) futures suggest a more cognitively and less socially structured scientific endeavor.

1. Introduction 
Since the introduction of an updated version of ChatGPT by OpenAI in November 2022 , the 
scientific uses and misuses of Artificial Intelligence (AI), more precisely large language models 
(LLMs) in research and teaching is no longer a fringe phenomenon, but discussed in the broad 
scientific and non-scientific public (Shen et al., 2023; Singhal et al., 2023; Teubne r et al., 2023). 
LLMs are artificial neural networks that generate human-like sounding texts based on a powerful 
natural language processing model, for example called Chat GP T meaning Generative Pretrained 
Transformer". LLMs process information extracted from books, online forums, social media, and 
news articles. Furthermore, LLMs rely on Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (Joshi 
et al., 2019). 
Focusing on the specific case of academia, we witness that LLMs are increasingly integrated into 
scientific writing processes (Samek et al., 2021). For example, LLM tools write texts that are 
hardly distinguishable from texts written by scientists or detectable by plagiarism software 
(Sharples, 2022). Moreover, LLMs already draft scientific publications (Thunström et al ., 2022). 
So far, the use cases of LLMs illustrate its ability to write plausible-sounding statements. However, 
to date, LLMs cannot replace academics, but may serve academics as a research writing aid. 
Besides its function as writing aid, LLMs could be utilized either for summarization or citation 
purposes. In 2023, context-sensitive summarization and citation still problematic despite recent 
progress, as newer programs still have problems to cite correctly or even invents citations (Tang 
et al., 2023; Thunström et al., 2022). Yet, it seems only a matter of time befor e LLM -based 
programs correctly cite literature context -sensitively at the correct locations within texts, 
especially if the LLM is coupled w ith citation databases and acquire full -text access to major 
publishers (“Tools Such as ChatGPT Threaten Transparent Science” 2023).  
Assuming that LLMs will be able to correctly cite and contextualize academic outputs (e.g. , 
articles), LLMs could offer personalized research support to individual researchers based on their 
research trajectories, interests and needs. LLMs could identify patterns, trends and gaps in large 
amounts of research data faster than human researchers  could. In addition, the translation 
capabilities of LLMs have increased rapidly, making it possible to access research and publications 
in many languages, bridging previous language gaps. These opportunities face the challenge that 
current unequal academic structures are inscribed in LLMs. Therefore we call a strong reliance on 
LLMs and the unquestioned belief in the power of black-boxed deep-learning algorithms – in our 
case LLMs – bot delusion after Dawkins’ (2006) The God Delusion. – The bot delusion may result 
in overtly strong faith in the summarization, citation, and productivity increasing potentia l of 
LLMs. Delusional academics refrain from critical reflection about the output and the 
circumstances, in which these models were trained.  For example, LLMs encounter pre -existing 
academic social structures and inequalities that affect the citation and publication landscapes, 
including inequalities in prestige, financial endowment, or embeddedness in research networks 
(Wu et al., 2019). In addition, national and organizational reward schemes, especially when using 
scientometric indicators and large bibliometric databases (de Rijcke et al. 2016; Shin et al. 2023), 
and disciplinary evaluation of research communication affect academic social structures for reward 
and reputation-gain. The article's central question is how the use of LLMs will a ffect academics' 
publication and citation behavior, i.e., could LLMs construct a bot delusion or motivate change in 
the scientific system? To address these inquiries, we conduct a theory -led thought experiment 
 
3 
(Brendel 2005) 1 since LLMs are not yet obtainable, and no data is available. The thought 
experiment enables us to predict possible futures of the widespread use of LLMs, and to construct 
scenarios for either the reproduction (stasis) or alteration (catharsis) of social inequalities within 
academia.  
By focusing on human behavioral issues and not addressing technological and other issues 
concerning LLMs, we define LLMs as a prime example of human-computer-interaction, in which 
a machine's program ming has intended and unintended, anticipated and unanticipated 
consequences for human action (Merton, 1936, 1968). Aware only of the intentional programming 
of LLMs training data selection, including Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback , we 
focus on anticipated consequences for academics’ social action, in our case academics’ publication 
and citations behavior. In Section 2, we discuss structural social conditions linked to the “Matthew 
Effect” (Merton, 1968)  of status accumulation in academia . Building upon the discussion of 
structural social conditions in academia and for the anticipated consequences of the training of 
LLMs in Section 3 , we unfold three scenarios coined “ reproducing content and status quo” , 
“content coherence evaluation” , and “content evaluation”  (Section 4) . In the scenarios we  
examine how the triad of structural features of academia, LLMs, and the bot delusion affect 
academia and discuss their potential to produce a sta sis or induce changes in the publication and 
citation landscape. To discuss the possible social behavior of scientists in our thought experiment, 
we use Merton's (1973) CUDOS norms of communalism, universalism, disinterestedness, and 
organized skepticism and Mitroff’s (1974) SPIOD counter-norms of secrecy, particularism, self -
interestedness and organized dogmatism  (Section 5). The idealized CUDOS norms reflect the 
catharsis opportunity offered by LLM s, and stasis is reflected in  the SPIOD counter -norms. As 
SPIOD only captures the individual counter -norms, we introduce communal counter -norms to 
capture academics’ stars, theory, method, findings, etc., loyal citation behavior. By summarizing 
the consequences, scenarios, and norms shown in three possible futures, we conclude our thought 
experiment (Section 6).  
2. Structural conditions for the unequal visibility and citability of publications 
Previous higher education and science research suggests that publication opportunity, visibility 
and citeability is characterized by extreme levels of inequality in academia (Kiesslich et al., 2021; 
Münch, 2014; Nielsen & Andersen, 2021; Wieczorek & Münch, 2023).  The main mechanism to 
explain such inequalities and their accumulation over time is captured by the “Matthew Effect” 
(Merton, 1968). The Matthew Effect is understood as path dependency that stems from actors 
having enjoyed a comparative advantage at a time t0 that has magnified into disproportionately 
higher advantages at t 1. In our case , four dimensions of the Matthew Effect are relevant for 
explaining academics’ publication and citation behavior  at an individual as well as a structural 
level: prestige hierarchy of researchers and disciplines , the access to the publication system,  
representation of disciplinary communities in bibliographic databases, and norms of collaboration 
and publication in disciplinary communities. 
Dimension 1, prestige hierarchy of researchers and institutions: At the individual level, reasons 
for the occurrence of the Matthew Effect regarding the publication - and citation inequalities 
include the seniority of a researcher, and his or her designation as principal in vestigator. As senior 
researchers and principal investigators are perceived as more prestigious than their co -authors, 
publications (co -)authored by these academics are being cited disproportionately more often

compared to publications issues by colleagues with similar content and of similar quality (van Dijk 
et al., 2014). At the organizational level, the Matthew Effect stems from differences in the prestige 
of universities and research institutes. Publications by authors affiliated with an Elite University 
are more likely to be published, and cited because of the attributed reputation of the institution 
(Teixeira da Silva, 2021). 
Dimension 2, prestige hierarchy of disciplines: Similar to individual and institutional hierarchies, 
academia is  characterized by a prestige hierarchy , in which disciplines with high degree s of 
formalization and predictive power are particularly esteemed (Cole 1983). This prestige hierarchy 
manifests in citation figures and the dissemination of concepts across disciplinary boundaries. In 
particular, the natural sciences export concepts to other academic communities and refrain from 
doing so the other way around (Benjafield, 2020; Fanelli & Glänzel, 2013). At the same time, 
scholars in the humanities and s ocial sciences increasingly align their publication structure with 
the STEM disciplines, despite being skeptical about their publication practices and metrics 
attached (Deutz et al., 2021; Hammarfelt & Haddow, 2018; Schneijderberg et al. 2022). These 
arguments combined indicate a dominance of STEM based on the chances of being cited in (more 
visible or higher ranked) journals across multiple disciplines and the subordination of social 
sciences and humanities under the STEM citation behavior. 
Dimension 3, access to the publication system : Disciplinary communities, whose main form of 
communication are English-language articles, are overrepresented in the bibliometric databases 
SCOPUS and Web of Science (Vera-Baceta et al., 2019). Even if they publish in English, similar 
applies to research communities situated in regions, which are not traditionally viewed as academic 
centers (e.g. Africa or South America). Only few journals situated in these parts of the world are 
covered by big bibliographic databases such as SCOPUS or Web of Science (Guzman-Valenzuela 
et al., 2023). Consequently, these ignore relevant and highly cited, but also regionally specialized 
research output which is not geared towards the Anglophone world  (Zavale & Schneijderberg, 
2020). The interplay of these communities with publication databases entails higher chances to 
publish in high -ranking journals and to dominate the status market of ideas. Additionally, the 
Journal Impact Factor serves as quality  bucket for all articles published in a journal – although 
citation counts are significantly skewed (Wang, 2014) due to interactions with the Matthew Effect 
on individual and institutional level. 
Dimension 4 , collaboration and publication in disciplinary communities : Collaboration norms 
linked to citation- and publication patterns differ between disciplines. These differences include, 
the size of research teams and co -authors per publication (Larivière, et al., 2015a, 2015b), the 
ability of scholars to acquire international collaborations (Kwiek, 2020), the chances to conduct 
interdisciplinary research (Fontan a et al., 2020), and the recognition of articles, conference 
proceedings, or monographs as high quality research outputs (Yair et al., 2022). 
Taken together, these four drivers of social inequality regarding visibility and citeability of 
scholarly publications are the stage, which LLMs enter. Yet how LLMs interact with these drivers, 
is open to debate, but how they possibly interact is subject of the next section. 
3. Anticipated consequences of the training of LLMs for the academic 
publication and citation system 
To train LLMs, books, online forums, social media, and news articles are used, in addition to 
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback. As LLMs rely on either openly available training 
data on the web (e.g., Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus; Raffel et al., 202 0), we have to consider 
 
5 
how the social structures in academia outlined above correlate with digital open knowledge sources 
(e.g., open access publishing and preprint servers) and closed knowledge sources (e.g., 
bibliometric databases). 
Starting with closed knowledge sources, we note that the Matthew Effect is amplified by the 
oligopoly of the SCOPUS and Web of Science databases. These databases act as business 
gatekeepers for ranked journals, which, for example, in the Elsevier business model means a 
cunning co-enforcement of SCOPUS indexed journals and publishing of some of those indexed 
journals. As the indexing is considered as quality indicator within (considerable parts of) academia 
(Ioannidis & Thombs, 2019), the anticipated consequences are that an article published in a journal 
with high impact factor is more likely to be cited compared to a similar content and quality article 
published in a low or no impact journal. However, any publisher could bypass the database 
oligopolies by seeking a cooperation with LLM -providers, which would boost any (non -indexed 
journal) publication, and, as intended consequence, citations. 
Considering hierarchies in academia, we note that the dissemination of concepts as well as the 
accumulation of citations are reinforced by coverage disparities in Web of Science and SCOPUS 
(Aksnes & Sivertsen, 2019). Therefore, both concepts and sources st emming from the natural 
sciences are expected to be cited with a higher likelihood across scientific disciplines. Moreover, 
bibliometric databases exhibit biases in favor of disciplinary communities that began publishing 
in journals earlier and more system atically.Furthermore, predominantly English -language 
publications are included in bibliometric databases. In fact, the coverage in bibliometric databases 
of publications published in the (semi)periphery is vanishingly small (Tennant, 2020). This yields 
a negative i mpact on the visibility of publications and ideas not located in the Anglo -American 
center of academic publishing (Confraria et al., 2017). The consequences of the SCOPUS and Web 
of Science selectivity are an under -coverage of particular disciplin es and geographic regions in 
said databases (Stahlschmidt & Stephen, 2020), for example Africa (Asubiaro & Onaolapo, 2023; 
Tijssen, 2007). The establishment of the Brazil-based, also publications in Portuguese and Spanish 
indexing ScieELO emphasizes the so cio-structural significance of bibliometric databases in 
academia. Such unequal access opportunities to databases combined with simultaneous pressure 
to publish in a journal or conference proceeding allowed the emergence of a publication economy 
of predatory journals and conferences, which particularly affects scientists in the (semi)periphery 
(Mills & Inouye, 2021).  
In addition, predatory and acknowledged open access (OA) journals and publishers that enable 
OA by charging article -processing charges (APC) are putting poorly funded scientists and 
countries at a severe disadvantage (Cantwell et al., 2018). In addition to  the APC-paywall, the 
existence of OA publishing opportunities are unevenly distributed between disciplinary 
communities (Bahlai et al., 2019). OA published articles are read and cited more frequently, which 
can impact reputation -gain, and career promotion s (Wang et al., 2015). However, many 
disciplinary communities have successfully established OA online journals by themselves, which 
are indexed in the Directory of Open Access Journals (https://doaj.org/). Finally, training 
opportunities also arise from the existence, disciplinary acceptance, and usage of preprint servers 
(e.g., SOCarXiv).   
4. Three scenarios for future development of academic publishing and 
citations 
Acknowledging the extremely dynamic state of LLMs development, LLMs bot delusion potential, 
and the difficulties to forecast its impact on academia, we focus on unintended but – in the course 
 
6 
of our thought experiment – anticipated consequences for social action according to their potential 
for either stasis, catharsis, or (elements of) both. In our case, stasis equates with the intensification 
of existing inequalities and the structures that bore them over time, thereby limiting the discursive 
space in academia and keeping up the faith in scientific authorities (e.g.  members of prestigious 
universities). Catharsis, in turn, means their overcoming. The following three scenarios assume 
that LLM-based programs will gain access to databases and repositories that include scholarly 
publications such as journal articles, preprints, and books. If LLMs learn when it is opportune to 
cite a source, then they could either adopt the currently existing patterns of citation in science, or 
be deliberately trained differently. The main takeaways are listed in Table 1 and the scenarios are 
discussed in detail below. 
The first scenario, which we name ‘reproducing content and status quo,’ assumes that LLMs learn 
that a context sensitive citation is to be chosen according to the (highest) number of citations, for 
example related to specific combinations of keywords. Accordingly, the most visible publications 
by the most prestigious researchers would occur disproportionately often  in LLMs citation 
suggestions. This would induce Matthew Effects, increase structural inequalities in the science 
system, and lead to the following anticipated consequences: publications issued by established 
scientists from a) Anglo-American countries, b) highly reputed universities, c) STEM-disciplines 
with high appeal to other subjects, and d) a journal-centric publication culture, are cited more often 
than other scientists are by LLMs.  
In addition, the size of subject communities, and their propensity to publish OA and preprints could 
increase their visibility disproportionally.  In turn, non-STEM disciplines, scholars , and non -
English outlets from the (semi-)periphery could be marginalized and occluded even further. This 
is especially true, if the services provided by LLMs are hidden behind a paywall.  
If scholars are socialized within this context and experience the application of LLMs as daily 
routine, they might either 1a) do not critically read or check the cited sources, 1b) focus on reading 
other sources or conducting research without link to previ ous research instead, or 1c) critically 
reflect on LLMs. The latter might lead either to the refusal of LLMs or the drive to improve or 
game the system. In the first two cases, the bot delusion is at play because scholars use LLMs 
unquestionably, whereas in the 1c) the scholars are either discouraged to use a tool which bears 
competitive advantages, or are deluded because they overestimate their chance to change the 
system. Either way, the group following the first two strategies might prevail, where as the group 
following the last one (1c strategy) might be seen as being against the rules of the academic game 
and might be driven out of academia along with their ideas. 
Our second scenario, which we call ‘content coherence evaluation ,’ assumes that the similarity 
between text-segments, for example from the methods or discussion sections , will be the main 
criterion for LLM programming to produce citation suggestions for scientists. For this to work, 
(full-)text access  to articles , for example,  in journal databases , on preprint servers, OA-
publications, and books is required. In this scenario, authors’ could choose not to cite the most 
cited publication(s) and/or cite additional or other publications, which would partially mitigate 
structural effects in academia.

Here, scholars could use LLMs twofold to improve their career prospect and to disproportionally 
increase their publication output and visibility. They could use LLMs for 2a) hyperspecialization, 
meaning that they focus on a single strand of research and dig into strands of research not 
summarized and cited by LLMs in their small domain. Furthermore, LLMs might identify research 
gaps in specialized domains. The time saved could then be reinvested into conducting research in 
this domain. 2b) LLMs could also alleviate some risks associated with i nterdisciplinary research, 
which is considered as high-risk, high-reward strategy because of lower publication rates (Leahey 
et al., 2017). Here, LLMs could identify research gaps, connect otherwise disconn ected thought 
products, or translate concepts from one domain to the other. This might speed up the research 
process enormously, especially if a number of highly specialized scholars collaborate, which then 
could complement their skills. However, the same constraints apply as discussed in 1a) to 1c) 
which may easily undo possible positive effects. 
Despite the chances outlined, t his scenario entails the following challenges. First, disciplinary 
communities with little propensity to publish in journals, OA publications, and preprint servers 
will be marginalized in the long run. Second, for monographs to remain eligible for citation, their 
full text must be accessible for LLMs. In this case, o lder, no longer licensed  monographs could 
further increase in citations or experience a citation renaissance if scanned and made available by 
google-books and other services. Otherwise, we may witness the eventual demise of monographs, 
and thus of certain disciplinary achievements. Third, OA publications in predatory journals might 
also be included in LLM-produced citation suggestions. On the one hand, what is a predatory 
journal is not always clear , for example  as the discussion about MDPI publisher illustrates  
(Oviedo-García, 2021). On the other hand, early career researchers and scientists external to a 
discipline might be ignorant to the predatory status of a journal . This may result in the growth of 
the predatory journal industry with little quality control and expensive price tags if scholars seek 
to get published.  
Extending scenario two, we call  the third scenario  ‘content evaluation ’. Using Reinforcement 
Learning from Human Feedback, further quality control for LLMs could be applied. Based on 2a) 
and 2b), scholars could rate how specific, interdisciplinary, intersectional, or international (e.g. 
regionally diverse), and relevant LLMs outputs might be. They could also curate the texts and lists 
of references. This curation might then be employed to retrain LLMs to provide more specific and 
detailed outputs. 
Boundary conditions are, first, that the similarity between text s and/or keyword combinations is 
the basis for citation suggestions by LLM-programs. A second boundary condition is the inclusion 
of in scenarios 1 and 2 omitted and marginalized texts within the scientific discourse. These might 
otherwise remain unconsidered as training data and – consequently – being left out of the model 
output. For this scenario to work out, scholars critically engaged in the literature and the output of 
LLMs as described i n 1c) are needed. If, however, LLMs were trained on input provided by 
scholars with “bot delusion”, then this scenario would quickly align to the first scenario. 
In this scenario, a LLM would offer citation suggestions including both the specific text passages 
to which the citation s refers and open access to the suggested publications . This enables 
researchers to evaluate whether a citation is appropriate, and in case of several algorithm-produced 
citation suggestions select one or more appropriate citations. Given the critical stance of scholars 
in regards to the sugges tions provided by LLMs, both combined  could firstly contribute to erase 
the memory of retracted publications (e.g., plagiarism)  and secondly to the demise of predatory 
journals. Overall, this could lead to a catharsis and thus profound changes towards more (citation-
 
9 
)equality in academia and the inclusion of previously unknown knowledge and potential for 
problem solving. 
5. Normative discussion of academics’ citation and publication behavior in 
times of LLMs 
In the three scenarios, we discuss how the evolution of LLMs could lead to  a reproduction of 
preexisting structurally conditioned inequalities in science (stasis), or to a catharsis that counteracts 
the structural inequalities or both. The three scenarios are constructed as ideal types that may serve 
as hypotheses for future testing . In fact, how the science system evolves depends on  the active 
usage of and the degree to which scholars suffer from the bot delusion, how human-data selection, 
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback, inclusion or exclusion of relevant  information 
and social groups (e.g. , papers published by authors situated in the so-called Global South), is 
performed, and if (mis-)application is minimized. To discuss the potential impacts of LLMs' usage 
behavior in academia , we use  Merton’s (1973) scientific CUDOS norms of Communalism, 
Universalism, Disinterestedness, and Organized Skepticism to capture the catharsis opportunity 
offered by LLM. To reflect the stasis possibilities we use Mitroff’s (1974) SPIOD counter-norms 
of Secrecy, Particularism, self-Interestedness and Organized Dogmatism. As SPIOD only captures 
the individual counter -norms, we introduce communal counter -norms to capture scholars’ loyal 
citation behavior.  
Of course, normative considerations such as Merton’s (1973) “Normative Structure of Science ,” 
i.e., the CUDOS, bear the risk of being considered as “social stereotypes” (Mulkay 1976: 647) . 
However, CUDOS as principles for robust scientific research  expressed by Merton (1973) in his 
remarks on the impact of the scientific system in the 1940s, seem still valid in the beginning of the 
21st century (Anderson et al. 2010). 
Beginning with the CUDOS -norms, LLMs could enable scientists to pursue the universalism, 
disinterestedness and organized skepticism norms. Focusing on LLMs supported citation behavior 
of scientists, Merton’s (1973) communalism norm ( “scientists openly sha re new findings with 
colleagues;” operationalized by Anderson 2000: 447) is  fulfilled, per se, and Mitroff’s (1974) 
secrecy counter norm ( “scientists protect their newest findings to ensure priority in publishing, 
patenting, or applications;” Anderson 2000: 448) does not apply. This is, however, only possible 
if 1) scholars are granted equal access to LLMs, 2) publications behind a paywall are made 
accessible, and 3) if LLMs are open to use for all. Other Mertonian norms relevant for the 
discussion are: 
• Universalism: “Scientists evaluate research only on its merit, i.e., according to accepted 
standards of the field.” 
• Disinterestedness: “Scientists are motivated by the desire for knowledge and discovery, 
and not by the possibility of personal gain.” 
• Organized Skepticism : “Scientists consider all new evidence, hypotheses, theories, and 
innovations, even those that challenge or contradict their own work.” 
As long as scholars do not blindly follow the suggestions of LLMs and suffer from the bot delusion, 
assuming the correctness and applicability of LLM s output, the CUDOS norms apply to the 
catharsis category in scenario 2 (LLMs cite literature that is appropriate in content conditioned on 
the availability of full texts ) and even stronger in scenario 3 ( LLMs as part of quality control in 
human-computer-interaction) in Table 1. From a normative perspective, CUDOS norms seem most 
 
10 
applicable to catharsis due to ‘content evaluation’ (scenario 3), and are represented to a lesser 
degree in ‘content coherence evaluation’ (scenario 2). Normatively, scenario 1 stasis enabled by 
LLMs seems to be driven by Mitroff’s particularism counter-norm which we formulate as follows: 
Scientists pro mote their (newest) findings to ensure priority in citations, publishing  or other 
research-related applications. Coherently, Mitroff’s (1974) s elf-interestedness norm (“scientists 
compete with others in the same field for funding and rec ognition of their achievements;” 
Anderson 2000: 448) and organized dogmatism (“scientists invest their careers in promoting their 
own most important findings, theories or innovations ;” Anderson 2000: 448) prevail. In scenario 
1 (‘content and status quo’) , organized dogmatism and self -interestedness seem to be promoted  
primarily by particularism: “Scientists assess new knowledge and its applications based on the 
reputation and past productivity of the individual or research group” (Anderson 2000: 448). 
This is related to hyperspecialisation (2a), but combined with in-group favoritism. Both could lead 
to crowding out of innovative research or competing ideas and the scholars following the 
associated lines of research. There is, in fact, a risk that this could be sold as universalism if schools 
of thought assume that their paradigm is the only valid one and employ strategies to optimize their 
publication- and citation curation behavior to optimize the suggestions presented to others using 
LLMs.  
Against the backdrop of the potential misuse of LLMs outlined above by members of different 
schools of thought , we argue that the SPIOD focus on the individual academics’ social status 
seeking, which  ranks higher than  the cognitive dimension of science, requires amendment for 
collectives. Modifying the operationalizations for particularism, self-interestedness and organized 
dogmatism by Anderson (2000)  of Mitroff (1974) , we suggest the individual complementing  
collective particularism, -interestedness and organized dogmatism counter-norms (C-PIOD): 
• Collective particularism: Scientists assess new knowledge and its applications based on 
their association with a theory, method or methodology, etc. to loyally promote the 
reputation and market the productivity of their group. 
• Collective-interestedness norm : to be more competitive  in publishing, acquisition of  
funding and receiving recognition of achievements, scientists strive for publications with 
or, at least, closely associated to the star scientist, school founder, etc., push citation counts 
(and journal metrics) primarily according to their loyal association with a theory, method 
or methodology, etc. 
• Collectively organized dogmatism: scientists invest their careers in loyally promoting the 
most important findings, theories , methods or innovations of godmothers and godfathers 
(school founders, star scientists, respected fellows, strategic partners, etc .). In addition to 
excessive citing, for example, in relevance and substance suggesting literature reviews, 
common means are the editing of collected works (with or without translation), writing of 
cheer-reviews of new books, etc.. In a more abstract way, these inconspicuous actions aim 
for the  establishment and /or maintenance of a n organized dogmatic  “protective belt”  
(Lakatos 1997: 133) to avoid attention shift away from a theory, method or methodology, 
etc.  
‘Collective particularism, ’ ‘collective-interestedness,’ and ‘collectively organized dog matism’ 
promote a particular “thought style” (Fleck 1981: 2; in German: Denkstil) as the very narrow 
cognitive condition or system within a particular “thought community” (Denkgemeinschaft; Fleck 
1981: 45): 
 
11 
“What we are faced with here is not so much  simple passivity or mistrust of new ideas as 
an active approach  which can be divided into several stages. (1) A contradiction to the  
system appears unthinkable. (2) What does not fit into the system  remains unseen; (3) 
alternatively, if it is noticed, either it is kept  secret, or (4) laborious efforts are made to 
explain an exception in terms that do not contradict the system. (5) Despite the legitimate  
claims of contradictory views, one tends to see, describe, or even  illustrate those 
circumstances, which corroborate current views and thereby give them substance. 
When Fleck (1981) wrote the above-cited lines in 1935, few (e.g., Bradford 1934) were thinking 
about the meaning of counting citations  and journal metrics,  and nobody imagined anticipat ing 
consequences of LLM on academics’ citation behavior. However, ignoring contradicting content 
and seeking for new content related to a particular theory, method, topic findings, etc.  and the 
decision to cite or not to cite a publication seem of a similar courses of conduct as described by 
Fleck (1981) – especially, in times of unprecedented growth -rates of publications ( Bornmann & 
Mutz 2015). In addition, since many decades, awarding citations and collecting large numbers of 
citations suffice to substantiate a particular  thought style (e.g., topic, method and theory), of 
course, supported by the Matthew Effect. 
6. Conclusion 
In the article at hand, we conducted a thought experiment to grasp the anticipated consequences 
installed in the fast development of LLM s and, consequently, their disruptive potential for the 
scientific system. Additionally, we investigated how they might induce a bot delusion, and a stasis 
or catharsis on academia and scientific disciplines therein . For this purpose,  we first introduced 
four dimensions of the Matthew effect linked to structural inequalities of academia. Second, we 
outlined anticipated consequences, which may occur if LLMs enter the academic stage and interact 
with pre -existing structures accountable for durable and increasing inequalities . Third, we 
presented three scenarios combining the dimensions of the Matthew effect and the anticipated 
consequences: Scenario 1 ‘reproducing content and status quo ’ assumes that LLMs learn that a 
context sensitive citation is to be chosen according to the (highest) number of citations. Scenario 
2 ‘content coherence evaluation ’ assumes that the similarity between text -segments will be the 
main criterion for LLM s programming to produce citation suggestions for scientists. Extending 
scenario 2, we named scenario 3 ‘content evaluation,’ which uses reinforced learning from human 
feedback further quality enhancement of LLMs. 
In the next step of the thought experiment, we discussed the three scenarios, drawing on Merton's 
CUDOS norms and Mitroff's SPIOD counter -norms (please note that for published research, 
Merton’s (1973) communalism norm is fulfilled, and Mitroff’s (1974) secrecy counter-norm does 
not apply. Accordingly, in the respective acronym s, the C (communalism) and S (secrecy) are 
crossed-out). Extending the individual counter -norms, we suggested three collective counter-
norms related to academics’ citation behavior  (C-PIOD). These are  ‘collective particularism’ 
(loyal promotion of the method or methodology, theory, findings, etc. of their thought community), 
‘collective-interestedness’ (loyal follower associated to the founding father(s) or mother(s) of the 
method or methodology , theory, findings , etc.  of their thought community ), and ‘collectively 
organized dogmatism’ (pushing citation counts (and journal metrics) as party loyalists to a theory, 
method or methodology, etc.).

To conclude, we anticipate the following LLM-induced future stasis and/or catharsis developments 
citation patterns (Table 2): 
1. Status quo science future (based on scenario 1) : In this scenario, LLM suggests citations 
ranked according to citation and publication volumes, i.e., prioritizes metrics over content. 
In this way, LLM replicates prevalent  academics’ citation behavior, thereby leading to 
stasis. This perpetuates the well-known social inequality structures in academia generated 
by status-keeping and -seeking of academics (reputation-gain via citation), financial means 
(pay for open access publications) and English language dominance. Maintaining the social 
structure also seems to be in the economic interest of journal publishers and owners of the 
WoS and SCOPUS databases. Stasis does not rule-out cognitive advancement of science, 
yet, most likely by established, eminent academics. They have the advantage through stasis 
that their privileges are perpetuated, which is supported by C-PIOD loyalty. 
2. Mixed-access science future (based on scenario 2) : LLMs use closed and open access 
publications from recognized outlets, and internet sources (e.g., reports, working papers, 
blogs and webpages) for suggesting citations. LLM citation suggestions are neither quality 
controlled with respect to the sources nor transparent from which text passages citation 
recommendations originate. Accordingly, scientists have to check sources of LLM citation 
suggestions, since predatory journals and unspecified internet sources are also accessed by 
 
13 
LLM. For closed science publications, for example indexed in WoS and Scopus databases, 
only the abstracts of publications are available, which does not enable academics to read 
all content for a comprehensive content comparison. Scenario 2 initially promises catharsis, 
as LLM suggestions are based on content rather than citation rank metrics. In comparison 
to this partial openness, the effort of quality control and the uncertainty of possibly citing 
dubious sources, ultimately, the catharsis is balanced by stasis, as academics continue with 
status quo science (as captured in future 1) and engage in ‘collective particularism’ and 
‘collective organized dogmatism’ as means of quality control. 
3. Open science future (based on scenario 3): In this future, LLM citation suggestion are based 
on content coherence , which  is coupled with Reinforcement Learning from Human 
Feedback. Continuing learning by LLM based on  human feedback enables further 
development of LLM citation suggestions, especially  concerning quality control. In the 
open science future, LLMs serve to identify research topic relevant diverse knowledge in 
publications for citation. Open access to all scientific publications enable academics’ in -
depth content evaluation, which could prevent academics’ regression into C-PIOD counter-
norms and metrics-induced reproduction of content and status quo. A catharsis could occur. 
In addition, a coupling with languages translation algorithms would be necessary to break 
the dominance of English as scientific language. 
 
If LLMs help s to identify relevant  literature, and if scientists take advantage of the resulting 
opportunity to consider new evidence, hypotheses, theories, and innovations, even those that 
challenge or contradict their own work, then the guiding norm of organized skepticism could be 
fulfilled (catharsis in scenario 3). However, this would also require that the universalism norm be 
fulfilled, that is, that scientists judge research only by its content merits, according to the accepted 
standards of the field. If the application of LLMs contribute to softening stasis in scenario 1, i.e., 
lessening of  particularism, self-interestedness and organized dogmatism, this  would promote  
scholarship (e.g., methods and theory development, and empirical research) and a science system 
better equipped to meet the many global challenges (e.g., expressed in the 17 Sustainable 
Development Goals). 
Nonetheless, our thought experiment yields a number of limitations. First, we extrapolate from the 
given developments and cannot truly anticipate if there will be emerging technologies in the 
domain of LLMs or normative settings in which our thoughts get obsolete. Second, we focus on 
the possibility to affect the current information-seeking and citation behavior of scholars who are 
already take part in the publication game. The socialization of scientists during their ( doctoral-
)training and how it is dealt  with LLM during studies may also be an important factor to be 
considered, but are out of focus in the current article. Finally, the discussion on LLMs might also 
be a chance to reflect on the academic publication - and citation system at large, leading to the 
implementation of new norms, which might mitigate the effects of LLMs on academia. 
Ultimately, the academic community at large must find a new consensus, or will transfer the 
responsibility to the scholars and scientists, which then might be free to follow the oligarchic trend. 
At best, our commentary might be of help for the community to find a common ground, or, at least, 
might help scholars to navigate through the fallacies of using LLMs (more or less) ethically.  Our 
three scenarios and science futures might provide working hypotheses or inspire other scholars to 
reflect on the interplay between LLMs, the possible bot delusion on individual and collective level, 
and persisting structures of inequality in academia.
